title: How to Pair Wine with Grilled Steak

steps.headline: Pin down the definitions for sweetness, acidity, and tannic.
steps.description:
These terms will help you understand the descriptions written on wine labels or in online wine reviews. When talking about wine, these words have the following meanings:
Sweetness: or a wine’s “dryness.” Sweet wine is high in sugar content, which will cause tingling in the tip of your tongue. Cheap wines and many Cabernet Sauvignons are often dry. Acidity: “tartness” or “zestiness.” Acidic wines feel lightweight and will leave your mouth wet, like you’ve just bitten an apple. Tannic: bitter, much like black tea. It will cause your mouth to feel dry, but don’t confuse this sensation with the dryness associated with a wine’s sweetness.

steps.headline: Recognize fruit flavors and body.
steps.description: Many wines feature a fruit flavor, like raspberry, blackberry, and blueberry. Full bodied wine describes wine that is heavy on your palette, whereas light bodied wine is not. The taste of a heavy vintage will linger in your mouth much longer than a light one. Some fruity wines include California Zinfandels, Argentinian Malbecs and Cabernet Sauvignons, and Merlots, especially those from Bordeaux. Generally, you can expect Cabernet Sauvignon, Malbec from Cahors, some Syrah, and some Zinfandel wines to be heavier bodied. Lighter bodied wines oftentimes include Cabernet Sauvignon wines from Argentina, Pinot Noir wines, Cabernet Franc, and Tempranillo.

steps.headline: Choose wine according to the key features of a main dish.
steps.description: Sauce, seasoning, and cooking method are the three main factors that will influence the taste of the main dish. A red wine that has a similar earthiness, spiciness, or suppleness as the main dish will naturally pair well. Try steak in a teriyaki sauce with a Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, Zinfandel, or red Bordeaux. Steak with a mustard sauce might go nicely with Syrah or Chianti wines. For example, if chicken marsala were part of the main spread, the dark, rich, earthy sauce would suit a soft bodied, supple red, like a high-end Zinfandel from California or a Cabernet Sauvignon from Argentina.

steps.headline: Round out key features of food with wine.
steps.description: A dry, acidic red, like a Chianti, Montepulciano, or Sangiovese, will cut the fat of red meat dishes, allowing you to enjoy the flavor more. The strong flavors of grilled dishes often go well with Cabernet Sauvignon wines. Sweet flavors can be balanced with spicier reds, like many Cabernet Franc, Grenache, Malbec, and Shiraz wines.

steps.headline: Opt for Merlot for a versatile choice.
steps.description: Merlot wines are usually soft and easy to drink. You can expect to find black cherry, plum, and herbal flavors in many Merlots. These wines will be less tannic (bitter) than other choices. Merlots pair well with virtually any menu. Many highly regarded Merlots are produced in Italy, California, Washington, Chile, and Australia. Medium price range bottles make a great gift.

methods.name: Selecting a Red According to Cut

steps.headline: Create a classic combo with a Cabernet.
steps.description: Cabernet wines will be one of the safest options for pairing with steak. The robust character will cut through fat, resulting in a smoother taste in the wine and richer flavor in the meat. If you ordered a mild-flavored steak (like one that is only lightly seasoned), Cabernet wines may be a little overpowering. Choose a milder wine in these instances, like a Pinot Noir or Merlot. If you’re looking for something different from the usual Cabernet, try a Cabernet blend instead. In some cases, the terms “Bordeaux blend” and “Cabernet blend” may be used interchangeably.

steps.headline: Serve filet mignon with Old World reds.
steps.description: Heavy New World red wines will dominate the subtle flavors of a filet. A better choice would be a Burgundy or Bordeaux. If you choose a Bordeaux, aim for a bold vintage. Generally, wines with softer flavor profiles will best bring out the qualities of filet mignon, like a truffle flavored Pinot Noir from Oregon.

steps.headline: Match the rich, bold flavor of rib eye with full-bodied reds.
steps.description: If your rib eye is especially fatty or smoky, a bold vintage, like a northern Rhone red, will keep your palette fresh. Rib eye with a neutral flavor is better suited for subtler vintages, like a California Cabernet or Syrah. If you want to take a risk with a bold red, do so when eating rib eye. The strong flavor and high marbling in this cut suits full-bodied, intense flavor profiles.

steps.headline: Bring out the flavor in a New York strip with a Bordeaux.
steps.description: The marbling in this cut really brings out its rich, savory flavor. Prioritize wines with medium acidity and a savory flavor profile, like a Bordeaux or a California Cabernet.

steps.headline: Try a Syrah with porterhouse cuts.
steps.description: You’ll generally want a full-bodied red with a porterhouse to balance out the high fat content. Northern Rhone reds and Syrah-based vintages are both excellent partners for porterhouse cuts. Because porterhouse steaks include two different cuts, pairing can be tricky. Other options you might enjoy include Bordeaux blends, Cabernet Franc, or Merlot.

steps.headline: Drink dry wines with steak.
steps.description: High-protein food, like steak and cheese, have a relatively high amount of fat. This can overwhelm your palette, making more subtle flavors difficult to taste. Dry, acidic wines cleanse your palette and enable you to enjoy your meal to its fullest. Some classic dry reds you might try with high-protein food include Cabernet, Sangiovese, Montepulciano, and Chianti. Sweet wines, like many red blends, Pinot Noirs, and Merlots, can similarly help balance the fattiness of protein rich.

steps.headline: Bring out herb flavors with a Bordeaux.
steps.description: If you have a taste for European wines, a Bordeaux will likely be right up your alley. These wines often have a more acidic flavor, which is perfect for rich and buttery sauces. Additionally, the savory notes of Bordeaux wine tend to go well with herb rubs and seasonings. Some common herbs used in grilled steak include rosemary, thyme, sage, basil, bay leaf, and more. Many special herb blends intended for grilled steak can be bought at your local grocery store or general retailers.

steps.headline: Match the savory flavors in beef with a Malbec.
steps.description: Malbec is one of the most popular wines in Argentina, where people consider it an ideal complement to steak. The earthy notes in Malbec wines work well with the savory flavors in the beef. Look for Malbec vintages from Argentina and Chile, which are countries known for their high-quality Malbec wines.

steps.headline: Accentuate sweet and/or spicy flavors with a Zinfandel.
steps.description: A sweet rub on your steak will usually pair well with California produced Zinfandel wines. California Zinfandels usually have berry notes, which can also be a refreshing counterpoint to dry chile sauces, like mole. Zinfandels are considered to be a versatile, food-friendly wine. They can even be used as a marinade for cuts of steak that are a little tougher than usual.

steps.headline: Pair with a dry riesling when you can't settle on a vintage.
steps.description: A dry riesling will usually have a moderate alcohol level (like 11% ABV or higher). The fruitiness and acidity of this wine make it an excellent match for any cut of steak you purchase. Some regions specialize in dry Rieslings. Try ones from Alsace (France), South Australia, Washington (US), New York (US), British Columbia (Canada), and Germany.

steps.headline: Select your wine according to how well done the meat is.
steps.description: When a piece of steak is well done, a juicy red, like medium price range Pinot Noir or a Gamay-Beaujolais, can greatly improve its flavor. Steaks that are medium to medium-rare pair well with earthy flavors, like the kind commonly found in Old World wine.
